text: These are people who certainly have not proved that they are worthy of the trust that we repose in them. As far as this job is concerned, let me also indicate that when it comes to BECE, most of the decisions are taken by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of supervisors and invigilators is done by the district exams officer, he explained. His comments come in the wake of a JoyNews Hotline investigation led by GH Probe’s Francisca Enchil, which uncovered disturbing levels of collusion at examination centres.
translated: [Ni abantu bari bimeze gutanga icyo bavuze ko bafite icyizere cyacu. Ku kibazo cy’akazi, nashimira kubivuga ko mu kazi ya BECE, amategeko y’ingero yose yafashwe na Serivisi ya Kinyarwanda ya Ghana. Kwa mfano, ubwiriza bw’abashinze na abayobera byafashwe na umuyobozi wa parike y’examu, yavuze. Ibi yavuze mu gihe cyo kubera ubushakashatsi bwakozwe na JoyNews Hotline bwari bwitwa Francisca Enchil wa GH Probe, bukomeje kubona uburyo bwo kwiyemeza mu ishuri.]
backtranslated: [It was people who were willing to give their feedback that they trusted us. On the employment issue, I would like to point out that in the BECE work, all the standards were set by the Ghanaian Rwandan Service. For example, the guidelines for the founders and administrators were set by the director of the park, he said. This was during a survey conducted by JoyNews Hotline that was Francisca Enchil of GH Probe, which continues to have a high level of self-confidence in the school.]

text: A variety of socioeconomic and cultural factors were identified as major barriers to accessing and utilizing MHCS. Over half of the women surveyed cited poverty, illiteracy, restrictions from their husbands, the distance to health facilities, and long queues as reasons for not using services. Additionally, over a third of the women pointed to cultural practices within their communities as a cause for delays in seeking care. These findings reveal that addressing maternal health in this region requires more than just improving clinical services; it also means tackling deeply rooted societal and personal challenges that women face daily.
translated: [Ubwoko bw'ibikorwa by'ubukungu n'uturage butandukanye byabonye ko ari byo bivuze kugera no kuganira serivisi za MHCS. Zaidi ya nusu ya ba mukecuru barije kubika ubukene, kutokwizwa, kubwirwa na bavandimwe, umbali kwa serivisi za afya, na amasaha maremare kuwunganisha kuganira serivisi. Kugira icyo gihe, zaidi ya gatatu ya ba mukecuru zarije kw'ibikorwa by'uturage mu muryango wabo kuriyo gihe cyo kwiruka kuganira serivisi. Ibi byerekana ko kuganira ubukene wa mukecuru mu karere haki ni gusa kuzamura serivisi za afya; kugira icyo gihe, kuganira ibikorwa by'uturage na by'umwirabura by'umwirabura by'umwirabura backtranslated: [A range of economic and social activities were found to be the means of accessing and negotiating MHCS services. More than half of the women reported poverty, lack of promotion, family informing, lack of health services, and long hours to negotiate services. To achieve this, more than a third of the women reported attending community services in their community at the time of the migration to negotiate services. This suggests that the integration of women into the health services is only to improve health services; to achieve this, the integration of community and social activities in the health services is to improve the health services of the population.

text: Despite his shortcomings, Unoka was a talented musician. He was a tall but very thin man with a slight stoop and a mournful look, which would disappear when he was drinking or playing his flute. His happiest moments came in the months after the harvest, when the village musicians would retrieve their instruments from above the fireplace. Unoka would join them, his face filled with pure joy and peace. Sometimes, other villages would invite Unoka and his band to teach them their tunes, and they would stay for several months, sharing their music.
translated: [Ndakurwanya kubura kwake, Unoka yari umuhanzi mwiza. Yari umugabo muremure kandi muto kubera, afite ibibazo n'umutima ushaje, ibyo byari bigaruka igihe yari kumwaga inzoga au kurya inanga yake. Igihe cy'umwaka cyari kigera mu minsi ikurikira ivyaro, abahanzi b'umudugudu barikwaga ibikoresho vyabo vya muzika kuva hejuru y'umuriro. Unoka yari kubashirira, umutima wake ukomeje umworo n'umwuka. Mw'igihe, imidugudu mingine yari kumpa Unoka na bendi yake kwigisha ivyinshi vyabo, nabo barabashirira kwa minsi mingi, bakishirira muzika yabo.]
backtranslated: [I object to his absence, Unoka was a good musician. He was a tall and short man, with a troubled and aged heart, which returned when he drank or ate his harp. When the year was about to end in the days following the harvest, the musicians of the village hung their musical instruments from the fire above. Unoka would be fond of them, his heart strengthened by the poor spirit. In the meantime, other villages would give Unoka and his band a lesson in many of their arts, and they would feast at their homes for many days, enjoying music.]

text: At the Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George’s Anglican Basic School in Accra, invigilators were captured openly demanding GH¢60 daily tokens, supervisors pocketed envelopes of GH¢400, and candidates were asked to contribute to an Aseda Offertory. John Kapi stressed that once WAEC provides feedback on such incidents, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take decisive action. And so when these issues come up, once the feedback goes to them, we [WAEC] expect that they would react appropriately and ensure that the right action is taken against the people, he said.
translated: [Mu ishuri rya Derby Avenue RC Basic School na St. George’s Anglican Basic School i Accra, abarizwa amakarita barahamagaye bari bapfa GH¢60 kwa kila siku, abashinze baramwegera amafaranga ya GH¢400, n’abanyeshuri barabwirwa kugira ngo kuva mu Aseda Offertory. John Kapi yavuze ko uko WAEC ibonye ibitekerezo ku kibazo, ni wajibu wa Ghana Education Service (GES) kugira icyo abantu bakeneye. N’uko ibibazo vyiza, uko ibitekerezo bigiye kubagezwa, tun [WAEC] tukizeza ko bazakomeza kugira icyo abantu bakeneye na kugira icyo abantu bakeneye kugira icyo abantu bakeneye kugira icyo abantu bakeneye.]
backtranslated: [At Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George's Anglican Basic School in Accra, cardholders were called who were charging GH¢60 per day, founders were approached for GH¢400, and students were told to leave the Aseda Offertory. John Kapi said that as WAEC received feedback on the issue, it was the responsibility of Ghana Education Service (GES) to meet the needs of the people. As the questions are good, as the feedback is coming, we [WAEC] hope that they will continue to meet the needs of the people and the people need to have what the people need to have what the people need to have.]

text: For rural communities in Ghana, especially in the Kumbungu district, access to and use of maternal healthcare services (MHCS) remain a significant challenge. This study set out to explore the specific barriers preventing women from utilizing these services and to evaluate the quality of care provided. The research adopted a mixed-methods approach, combining both quantitative and qualitative data to get a comprehensive view of the situation. This phased design involved surveying 441 pregnant and postpartum women and conducting interviews with 20 healthcare providers. A facility checklist was also used to assess the state of clinics, including the availability of essential drugs and equipment.
translated: [Urwego rwo kubona na kugena serivisi za afya ya mababyeyi (MHCS) mu mirenge ya Ghana, haswa mu karere ka Kumbungu, ni ikibazo gikomeye. Ushusho huu watejeje kwiga ibibazo byo mu kigero byakubangamira abagore kugena serivisi hizi no kumenyesha ubora w’ubuvuzi bwaberekerwa. backtranslated: [The level of access to and appointment of Maternal Health Services (MHCS) in rural Ghana, especially in the Kumbungu region, is a major issue. This study examined the scale of barriers that prevent women from appointing these services and informed the quality of their care. This study was conducted by the National Institute of Health (NIH) in the United States of America, and was funded by the National Institute of Health (NIH) in the United Kingdom.

text: Okonkwo was a man of great renown throughout his nine villages and even beyond, a fame built entirely on his own remarkable achievements. At just eighteen years old, he brought honor to his village by defeating Amalinze the Cat, a legendary wrestler who had been undefeated for seven years. Amalinze earned his nickname because his back never once touched the earth. The old men of the village considered Okonkwo's victory one of the fiercest fights they had ever seen.
translated: [Okonkwo yari umugabo w'umwirabura mwinshi mu miryango yake itandatu na kure, umwirabura watewe n'ibikorwa by'ingenzi by'umwirabura we. Akiwa afite imyaka kumi na nane gusa, yagiriza umwirabura umujyi wake kwa kubwira Amalinze Igihe, umukinnyi w'ingoma wari warushijwe kwa myaka saba. Amalinze yari atuyeze izina rye kubera ko umugongo we wari utaraba k'umuhanda. Abakuru b'umujyi bari bamaze kubona ingoma zikomeye nk'izo Okonkwo yari yabwiye.]
backtranslated: [Okonkwo was a black man who was the largest of his six distant relatives, a black man who was affected by the important actions of his blackness. At only eighteen years old, he accused a black man in his town of telling Amalinze Tempo, a crown prince who was seven years older. Amalinze had already made his name because his back was not yet to the road. The elders of the town had already seen great kingdoms like the ones Okonkwo had told.]

text: Muntaka assured the committee of full logistical and secretariat support from the Ministry and urged them to partner with civil society organizations, development partners, and faith-based institutions in carrying out their work. He described the task as heavy but honorable, stressing that the people of Gbenyiri and surrounding communities were looking up to the committee as instruments of peace, reconciliation, and healing.
translated: [Muntaka yashimye komite y'ubufatanye bw'umwanzuro na serikali ya minisiteri, akababwira kw'abafatanyabikorwa n'amasosiyete y'abaturage, abafatanyabikorwa b'umuryango w'abibumbye, na madamu y'ibikorwa by'imana mu kubikora. Yabwiye ko umwanzuro ni mwinshi ariko ni w'umwirabura, akabaza ku kubwira ko abaturage ba Gbenyiri na komuniti zirikurira zirababwira komite nk'inzangano z'umwuka, z'ubumwe, na z'uburabura.]
backtranslated: [Muntaka praised the decision-making cooperation committee and the ministerial government, telling them of the partnerships with civil society, the UN partners, and the gods of action in making it. He said the decision was a lot but black, and asked them to tell the people of Gibraltar and the communities complaining about them as committees of spiritual hatred, solidarity, and lack of resources.]

text: The study also shed light on significant facility-based challenges that compromise the quality of care. A key issue was the inadequate number of midwives, which likely contributes to the long queues women reported. Additionally, the absence of essential equipment and drugs was a major problem. For example, health service providers specifically recommended a greater number of trained midwives and the provision of critical logistics like ultrasound machines and proper delivery equipment to ensure effective and high-quality care.
translated: [Ubushakashatsi kandi bwerekanye ibibazo bikomeye by’ikigo bigabanya ubora w’ubuvuzi. Ikibazo cy’ingenzi cyari ukubwa dore d’ababyeyi, bikaba byagira uruhare mu kubura kw’abagore. Kugira ngo, kutabira kwa ibikoresho na madawa ya kibazo byari ikibazo kinini. Kwa mfano, abatoza serivisi za afya bategetse kuboneka kwa ababyeyi bazima zaidi na kugira ibikoresho by’ingenzi nko kwa mashine za ultrasound na ibikoresho by’imibonano by’imibonano by’imibonano backtranslated: [The study also showed that severe institutional problems reduce the quality of care. The main issue was the size of the parents, which could contribute to the lack of women. Therefore, the availability of equipment and medication for the problem was a major issue. For example, health service providers expect the availability of more healthy parents and access to essential equipment such as ultrasound machines and equipment for sexual health care. The study also found that the availability of adequate health care for the parents was a major problem.

text: Okonkwo was an imposing figure, tall and massive with a severe expression, a result of his bushy eyebrows and wide nose. His breathing was so heavy that his family could hear it from their own houses when he slept. When he walked, his heels barely touched the ground, making him seem poised to pounce on someone—which he often did. He had a slight stammer, and in moments of anger, he would resort to his fists when words failed him. He had no patience for men who were not successful, and this sentiment stemmed from his deep-seated shame for his own father.
translated: [Okonkwo yari umuntu w'ingenzi, w'uburebure bwinshi n'umutwe mwinshi, uruhu rwe rwose rwaragaye kubera imyanya y'amaso y'aragaye n'umunwa mwinshi. Umwuka we wari ukomeye kubera ko umuryango we wabamwumva wakiri mu nzu zabo wakiri. Wakorera, amaguru y'abanyuma yake yagwa kugwa k'umuhanda, akaba ari mu kibuno cyo kugwa k'umuntu—kandi yabaga akora. Yari afite umwuka ushobora kugwa, na mu gihe cy'ikibazo, yagwa k'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya y'umwanya backtranslated: [Okonkwo was a prominent, tall man with a big head, his entire skin was paralyzed from his large eyes and mouth. His breath was strong because his family could hear him from their living quarters. At work, his back legs would fall off the road, and he was in a falling-off position while working. He had a breath that would fall off, and in a crisis, would fall off the road. He was a very tall man, with a large head, his whole skin was paralyzed from his eyes and mouth. His breath was strong because his family could hear him from their living quarters.

text: The West African Examinations Council (WAEC) says officials implicated in acts of corruption during the Basic Education Certificate Examination (BECE) will be blacklisted from ever taking part in its activities again. Speaking on JoyNews’ PM Express on September 8, WAEC’s Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Council cannot continue to work with individuals who have betrayed the trust placed in them during national examinations.
translated: [Ushirika wa Ekizami wa Afurika ya Magharibi (WAEC) ushema ofisieli waliotajwa kuhusika na vitendo vya rushwa wakati wa Ekizami cha Shahada ya Kwanza ya Elimu (BECE) bazabarurwa kutokwenda kushiriki katika shughuli zake tena. Akiongea kwenye PM Express ya JoyNews mnamo Septemba 8, Mkurugenzi wa Masuala ya Umma wa WAEC, John Kapi, alisema Baraza halitaweza kuendelea kufanya kazi na watu binafsi ambao wamesaliti imani iliyowekwa kwao wakati wa majaribio ya kitaifa.]
backtranslated: [The West African Examinations Council (WAEC) announces that officials identified as having been involved in corrupt practices during the First Educational Certificate Examination (BECE) will be barred from participating in its activities again. Speaking on JoyNews' PM Express on September 8, WAEC's Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Board would not be able to continue working with individuals who have betrayed their trust during the national examination.]

text: The study found that while a high percentage of women did engage with some maternal health services—87.5% attended antenatal care (ANC), 87.3% had a skilled delivery, and 84.8% had a postnatal care (PNC) visit—the frequency of care was a concern. A little over half of the participants (53.4%) had the recommended four or more ANC visits, and nearly half (46.9%) didn't register until their second trimester. These figures highlight a gap between initial access and consistent, timely utilization of services, suggesting that women may be facing obstacles that prevent them from fully engaging with the healthcare system throughout their pregnancies.
translated: [Ubushakashatsi bwagaragaje ko, mu gihe cyane cy'abagore bari bafashe serivisi z'ubuvuzi bw'umubyeyi—87.5% byari byarageze kwa serivisi z'ubuvuzi kabla y'umwana avuka (ANC), 87.3% byari byarageze kwa serivisi z'ubuvuzi w'umwana avuka, na 84.8% byari byarageze kwa serivisi z'ubuvuzi nyuma y'umwana avuka (PNC)—kubera serivisi zose z'ubuvuzi zikaba ziri ku kigero. Ikiyongeraho, abantu bapima 53.4% byari byarageze kwa serivisi z'ubuvuzi kabla y'umwana avuka (ANC) zikaba ziri zingana na zinapimwa, na abantu bapima 46.9% byari byarageze kwa serivisi z'ubuvuzi kabla y'umwana avuka (ANC) zikaba ziri zingana na zinapimwa. backtranslated: [The study found that, at the peak of women receiving maternal care services, 87.5% had access to antenatal care (ANC), 87.3% had access to maternal care services, and 84.8% had access to postnatal care (PNC) services due to the availability of all antenatal care services. Additionally, 53.4% of women had access to antenatal care (ANC) and were aware of their screening status, and 46.9% of women had access to antenatal care (ANC) and were aware of their screening status. This finding highlights the gap between the availability of antenatal care services and the availability of antenatal care services, which is the same for women who are pregnant, pregnant, pregnant, and breastfeeding, and the availability of antenatal care services, which is the same for women who are pregnant, pregnant, and breastfeeding.

text: The crowd held its breath as the drums beat and the flutes sang. Amalinze was a clever opponent, but Okonkwo was just as skilled, and as slippery as a fish in water. Both men were incredibly strong, their muscles and nerves straining to the point of almost breaking. But in the end, Okonkwo emerged victorious. This monumental win was just the beginning of his legacy. Over the next twenty years, his fame spread like a wildfire, fueled by his unwavering resolve and personal triumphs.
translated: [Umwambaro wari wumvise kuva inzoga zikururuka na inanga zikururura. Amalinze yari umukandida w’ingenzi, ariko Okonkwo yari wenyine na wenyine, n’umuhoro kama ifi mu mazi. Abantu babiri bari bafite imbaraga zikomeye, amaguru yabo n’amaso yari yikomeye kugira ngo yababaye. Ariko mu mwisho, Okonkwo yari yatsinze. Ushindi huu w’ingenzi wari wawe wambere wa uruhago rwe. Mu myaka ishumi na mirongo iri imbere, umwuga we wari wumvise kama umuriro wa mazi, wufashwe n’umwete w’umwete na umwete w’umwete.]
backtranslated: [The dress had been heard from the falling wine and the falling harp. The guards were the main contender, but Okonkwo was alone and alone, with a voice like a fish in the water. Two men were very strong, their legs and eyes were too strong to suffer. But in the end, Okonkwo had won. This important voice was the first of his joke. For the next decades, his career had felt like a water fire, consumed by zeal and zeal.]

text: The seven-member mediation committee will be chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of the committee include Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and chair of the Committee on Lands and Natural Resource in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chair of Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) who will be the secretary.
translated: [Komite ya maderakati itajumuisha watu saba, itaongozwa na Bwana Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Wengine wajumuisho wa komite hiyo ni Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP na Mwenyekiti wa Kamati ya Ardhi na Maliasili ya Bunge), Padri Lazarus Annyere (Mwenyekiti wa Baraza la Amani la Savannah), Dk Festus Aubyn (Mtandao wa Kusimamia Amani katika Afrika ya Magharibi), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Mkurugenzi wa Muda wa Taasisi ya Wanawake, Vijana, Amani na Usalama, Kituo cha Mafunzo ya Amani cha Kimataifa cha Kofi Annan), Profesa Ramatu Alhassan na Dk George Amoh (Katibu Mkuu wa NPC) ambaye atakuwa katibu.]
backtranslated: [The seven-member non-partisan negotiating committee, chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of the committee include Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Land and Natural Resources), Father Lazarus Annyere (Chairman of the Savannah Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (Peacebuilding Network in West Africa), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Interim Director of the Institute for Women, Youth, Peace and Security, Kofi Annan International Peace Education Center), Professor Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (NPC Secretary General) who will serve as secretary.]

text: To improve maternal health in the Kumbungu district, both study participants and service providers offered actionable recommendations. Women suggested focusing on public education about maternal care, enforcing free MHCS, and improving the local road network to make facilities more accessible. Providers emphasized the need for more midwives and better equipment. The study concludes that both governmental and non-governmental organizations must increase investment in maternal health and address the broader socioeconomic issues affecting women. This comprehensive approach, tackling both healthcare system deficiencies and community-level barriers, is essential for truly improving maternal health outcomes.
translated: [Mu kugabanya umwana w'abagore mu karere ka Kumbungu, abanyeshuri n'abafasha umwana bafashe amakuru y'agaciro. Abagore bategetse kuzingirwa k'ubumenyi bw'abaturage kuhusu kuboneza umwana, kwishyura serivisi za kuboneza umwana, n'imbere mu kubaka ibarura vy'ingoma ili amashuri y'uboneza umwana azaboneke. Abafasha umwana bategetse kuboneka kwa midwife zinshya na ibikoresho bishya. Ushusho wa raporo utangaza ko amakoperative y'igihugu na y'abikorera mu kigihugu zinahitamo kongera kugabanya umwana w'abagore na kurengera ibibazo vya kijamii vyabagore. Ushusho huu wose, wohereza ibibazo vy'abafasha umwana na ibibazo vy'abaturage, ni ngombwa kugabanya umwana w'abagore.]
backtranslated: [By reducing female childbirth in Kumbungu County, students and caregivers have collected valuable information. Women have demanded the protection of public knowledge about child care, payment for child care services, and the establishment of a government census to determine which child care schools will be available. Caregivers have demanded the availability of new midwives and new equipment. The report's image reveals that state and private sector organizations across the country are choosing to further reduce female childbirth and to prevent gender-based social problems. This image, which considers both caregiver issues and social issues, is important for reducing female childbirth.]

text: Unoka, Okonkwo's father, had passed away ten years prior. He was a man known for his laziness and carelessness, living only for the present with no thought for the future. Any money he managed to acquire—which was a rare occurrence—he would immediately spend on palm-wine, gathering his neighbors for a celebration. He believed that to see a dead man's mouth was to see the foolishness of not eating what you had in life. Unoka was also deeply in debt, owing money to nearly every one of his neighbors.
translated: [Unoka, se wa Okonkwo, yapfuye imyaka kumi mbere. Yari umugabo wamenyekanyo kwa kugira umutima dushimishije na kugira umutima ushaka, ari kw'igihe gikize k'ubanza, asigwa n'umwanya wa kuzingira. Ibiro byose yabigishije, ariko byari ibi bitabiri—yabikwisha kugurisha ku ngwino ya palmu, akigera abaturage be kuganira. Yari afite imyitwaro ko kureba umunwa wa muntu wapfuye ni kureba ubuhanga bwa kutagira icyo wari ufite mu buzima. Unoka yari pia yari mu masezerano y'inguzanyo, yari yinjije mu masezerano y'inguzanyo kwa abaturage be benshi.]
backtranslated: And the king of the Philistines said to the priests, "Behold, the king of the Philistines has come to you, and he has brought you into the land of Egypt, and has given you a land of Canaan, and has given you a land of Canaan, and has given you a land of Canaan.
